Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239.proposition: The Boston Municipal Court, Dorchester Division, has jurisdiction pursuant to the court’s statutory grant to hear landlord–tenant and related civil actions (see generally Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 239), and venue is proper in the Dorchester Division because the Premises are located in Dorchester and the events giving rise to this action occurred there.

Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: See, e.g., Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing that tenants’ right to habitable conditions and quiet enjoyment is an implied covenant enforceable by tenants); see also authorities cited below.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (general landlord–tenant statutes; see, e.g., provisions concerning residential tenancies and related topics)

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, \u00a7127A.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, §127A (authorizing the Department of Public Health to promulgate the State Sanitary Code)

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (Massachusetts State Sanitary Code — Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation; heating requirements and standards for habitable housing)

Mass. R. Civ. P..proposition: Mass. R. Civ. P. (applicable procedural rules for civil actions in Massachusetts courts)

Hilder v. St. Peter, 470 A.2d 776 (Vt. 1.proposition: Hilder v. St. Peter, 470 A.2d 776 (Vt. 1983) (recognizing landlord obligations to maintain habitable premises; persuasive)
Hilder v. St. Peter, 470 A.2d 776 (Vt. 1.case_name: New England Telephone & Telegraph Co. v. Public Utilities Commission
Hilder v. St. Peter, 470 A.2d 776 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Hilder v. St. Peter, 470 A.2d 776 (Vt. 1983), but a Maine Public Utilities Commission ratemaking decision involving New England Telephone, dealing with utility rates, tax issues, and capitalization of expenses. It does not concern landlord-tenant law, habitability standards, or landlord obligations to maintain habitable premises. Therefore, this opinion does not support the stated proposition about landlord habitability obligations.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 470 A.2d 776 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: As we observed in New England Telephone & Telegraph Co. v. Public Utilities Commission, 390 A.2d at 23, “In order to carry out its rate-making obligation, a regulatory commission must be able to go beyond the utility’s books of account.” Its rate-making obligation is principally to ensure that rates are just and reasonable, balancing the essential revenue needs of the utility with the value of service to the consumer and his ability to pay. Central Maine Power Co. v. Public Utilities Commission, 150 Me. 257, 109 A.2d 512 (1955); 35 M.R.S.A. § 51.

Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.proposition: Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (1974) (landlord duty of habitability; persuasive)
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that California common law recognizes an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases and that breach of that warranty can be raised by tenants as a defense in unlawful detainer actions. This directly establishes a landlord duty of habitability and is frequently cited as persuasive authority on that doctrine, including beyond California. The proposition accurately reflects both the subject and the significance of the case.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.relevant_excerpt: “For the reasons discussed below, we have determined that the Hinson court properly recognized a common law implied warranty of habitability in residential leases in California, and we conclude that the breach of such warranty may be raised as a defense in an unlawful detainer action. … Thus, we conclude that Civil Code section 1941 et seq. do not preclude the development of new common law principles in this area, and we now hold that a warranty of habitability is implied by law in residential leases in California.”

Armbruster v. State St. Trust Co., 355 M.raw_text: Armbruster v. State St. Trust Co., 355 Mass. 284 (1969)
Armbruster v. State St. Trust Co., 355 M.proposition: Armbruster v. State St. Trust Co., 355 Mass. 284 (1969) (discussing landlords’ obligations under Massachusetts law — cited for general landlord‑tenant principles)
Armbruster v. State St. Trust Co., 355 M.case_name: Ultronic Systems Corp. v. Board of Assessors of Boston
Armbruster v. State St. Trust Co., 355 M.support_reasoning: The opinion is a state tax case about whether certain electronic equipment qualifies as exempt personal property under Massachusetts tax law. It does not discuss landlord‑tenant relationships, lease obligations concerning real property, or landlords’ duties under Massachusetts law. Using this case as authority for general landlord‑tenant principles is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by its reasoning or holding.
Armbruster v. State St. Trust Co., 355 M.relevant_excerpt: "Ultronic is a Delaware corporation qualified to do business in the Commonwealth. Its principal place of business in the Commonwealth is at 141 Milk Street, Boston. The city assessed taxes, which were paid, on its personal property for the three years in issue. The taxpayer claims an exemption under G. L. c. 59, § 5, Sixteenth (2)..."

Adkins v. Lafayette, 363 Mass. 792 (1973.proposition: Adkins v. Lafayette, 363 Mass. 792 (1973) (Mass. cases addressing landlord obligations and tenant protections)
Adkins v. Lafayette, 363 Mass. 792 (1973.support_reasoning: The opinion in Adkins v. Lafayette is a criminal case involving a murder conviction, focusing on the admissibility of dying declarations, effectiveness of counsel, and propriety of prosecutorial argument. It does not address landlord-tenant law, landlord obligations, or tenant protections in any way. Therefore it cannot be used as authority for the stated proposition about Massachusetts landlord obligations and tenant protections.
Adkins v. Lafayette, 363 Mass. 792 (1973.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant appeals under G. L. c. 278, §§ 33A-33G, from his conviction of murder in the second degree on an indictment charging him with murder in the first degree… The defendant has argued three assignments of error. He claims that the statements made by the victim were improperly admitted in evidence as dying declarations. He next contends that the closing argument of his then counsel was so inadequate that it virtually constituted an admission of guilt… Finally, he argues that the assistant district attorney committed reversible error in his closing argument…”

Coopers v. City of Boston, 389 Mass. 94.raw_text: Coopers v. City of Boston, 389 Mass. 94 (1983)
Coopers v. City of Boston, 389 Mass. 94.proposition: Coopers v. City of Boston, 389 Mass. 94 (1983) (public health and housing code enforcement principles)
Coopers v. City of Boston, 389 Mass. 94.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns insurer bad faith, refusal to settle within policy limits, and liability under Massachusetts consumer protection law (G.L. c. 93A) and insurance practices (G.L. c. 176D). It does not address public health, housing conditions, or housing or sanitary code enforcement. Using this case as authority for ‘public health and housing code enforcement principles’ is therefore inaccurate and out of context.
Coopers v. City of Boston, 389 Mass. 94.relevant_excerpt: We turn now to consider whether the findings as to bad faith were warranted. American Mutual does not challenge that the breach of an insurer’s duty to act in good faith to settle a claim brought against an insured within the policy limits… provides a sufficient basis for recovery under c. 93A, § 9. Rather, it argues that there was insufficient evidence to support the findings that it acted in bad faith by offering less than the policy limits of $20,000 in settlement.

Annot., 88 A.L.R.3d 1039.proposition: Annot., 88 A.L.R.3d 1039 (cases addressing the covenant of quiet enjoyment and landlord liability; persuasive secondary authority)

G. L. c. 111.proposition: G. L. c. 111 cases interpreting the State Sanitary Code and municipal enforcement (collected decisions applying 105 CMR standards)
